title: Minimizing waste while allowing you to expand your palate
text:
Too Good To Go is just that too good of an app at what it does, which it aims to do in minimizing food waste. While the premise of each purchase is that you will receive fair market value equal to what you purchase, there is the inherent uncertainty and with it gamble that today the store you bought a surprise bag from will have lots of leftovers. As for the stores themselves, this app allows for them to minimize food waste, make a few dollars off of their leftovers, and reach a potentially new demographic of customer who at first try that store via this app but over time can become a new loyal customer. 

I believe in the idiom ‚Äúwaste not, want not‚Äù and with this app and how it seeks to achieve its purpose, I am convinced that TGTG has found that right balance in doing its part to help reduce food waste. Indeed, I kinda feel like a 5-star rating does injustice to the wonderful work that this app seeks to do.

title: Expensive and annoying
text: Everything‚Äôs always a ‚Äúsurprise‚Äù and just really expensive. I thought this would be a good way to save, but it‚Äôs not. You‚Äôre better off getting meals from Tesco‚Äôs clearance section.

title: Love it

title: My favorite app

title: Great concept
text: In theory this is an awesome concept. Saving food, saving money. It‚Äôs a great idea. But in practice it doesn‚Äôt work as smoothly. Many of these places, especially the markets, just toss in their inedible rotten food. The purpose is meant to be for stuff past the sell by date, not stuff that‚Äôs already rotten.

title: Doesn‚Äôt quite hit the mark

title: Great opportunity!
text: Too Good to Go presents you with some unique opportunities:  you get to try the food at a restaurant or market, paying only 1/3 of the regular prices, AND you save food from being wasted!  If the food was otherwise going to City Harvest or another food-gathering and distribution organization, I might feel differently.  But the restaurants don‚Äôt have that much food to make pick-ups cost-efficient.  So Too Good to Go fills that niche!

title: Saving lots of money!
text: I‚Äôve used it 3 times already, and I‚Äôve been very pleased. 1st time I paid $5.99 and got 6 medium sized pigs-in-a-blanket and two larger ones! Excellent value. I froze them. 2nd time I got Snap Kitchen which is ready made meals that are out of my price range usually, but I got 8 meals for $10. Unbelievable deal. Tonight I paid $10 again, this time at Whole Foods and got chicken enchiladas, salads and maple sweet potatoes. I will use it next time to get donuts for my coworkers (I will tell my coworkers they‚Äôre a day old).

title: Good bargains to be had
text: I‚Äôve gotten several bag from several different places. I‚Äôve gotten everything from basically a full meal to rice and potatoes (they were very good). It has been fun trying new places.  You seem to do the best with bags from bakeries:Pretty much guaranteed to be pastries. The one thing I wish is that you would get a text when a favorite vendor lists a bag. It is so frustrating to open the app and seeing that a place I‚Äôve been hoping to try sold out two hours ago.

title: Great Platform for Cheap & Good Food

title: Business was not open; refund takes too long.
text: The business I was supposed to pick up my reserved bag from was actually closed without any notice. On top of that, TGTG takes weeks to give any direct refunds back. Time is wasted in more ways than one.

title: Good but reviews
text: Why can‚Äôt we see the reviews anymore? I wanna know if the stores offering to go bags are worth it or not. I don‚Äôt like to throw away my money just because you guys want to get rid of the reviews.

title: Pastries and pizza
text:
The app is fine. The problem is that 70% of the stores are coffeehouses and bakeries, 20% are pizzerias, and the rest are miscellaneous. If you‚Äôre into baked goods and pizza, you‚Äôre all set. Otherwise, you‚Äôll starve trying to order food from this app.

Note that I tried a few locations in LA with the same result. It‚Äôs a little better in SF but really not that much.

title: Allergen warning, whats the point
text:
When the business marks ‚Äòsurprise bag‚Äô they don‚Äôt have to disclose possible allergens. The allergy button is simply. Of course every business marks ‚Äòsurprise bag‚Äô, they don‚Äôt know end of the day inventory. Y‚Äôall need to give subcategories for surprise bags, prompt businesses to disclose allergens, or remove some of the mystery of a surprise bag.

If i want to save money and the earth by buying left over groceries, I should at least be able to ensure it‚Äôs not a bag of peanuts.
